front.title: Problem Statement for the Reservation of Top-Level Domains in the Special-Use Domain Names Registry

abstract.t: The dominant protocol for name resolution on the Internet is the Domain Name System (DNS). However, other protocols exist that are fundamentally different from the DNS, but which have syntactically-similar namespaces.

When an end-user triggers resolution of a name on a system which supports multiple, different protocols for name resolution, it is desirable that the protocol to be used is unambiguous, and that requests intended for one protocol are not inadvertently addressed using another.

RFC 6761 introduced a framework by which, under certain circumstances, a particular domain name could be acknowledged as being special. This framework has been used to make top-level domain reservations, that is, particular top-level domains that should not be used within the DNS to accommodate parallel use of non-DNS name resolution protocols by end-users and avoid the possibility of namespace collisions.

Various challenges have become apparent with this application of the guidance provided in RFC 6761. This document aims to document those challenges in the form of a problem statement, to facilitate further discussion of potential solutions.

section.title: Terminology
section.t: Clear and unambiguous use of terminology is important for the clear formulation of any problem statement. The DNS protocol suffers from imprecise and overloaded terminology (e.g. see ) without confusing matters further with terms and concepts from other naming systems that are similar, but different.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The dominant protocol for name resolution on the Internet is the Domain Name System (DNS), originally specified in and . However, other name resolution protocols exist that are fundamentally different from the DNS, but which make use of syntactically-similar namespaces.

When an end-user triggers resolution of a name on a system which supports multiple, different name resolution protocols, it is desirable that the protocol to be used is unambiguous and that requests intended for one protocol are not inadvertently addressed using another.

introduced a framework by which, under certain circumstances, a particular domain name could be acknowledged as being special. This framework has been used to make a reservation (a part of the DNS namespace that should not be used by the DNS protocol) to accommodate non-DNS name resolution protocols and to avoid the possibility of namespace collisions.

describes seven questions which should be considered when deciding whether a domain name is special. Domain names that are acknowledged to be special are inserted into the Registry, the initial contents of which included 25 entries; four were top-level domains (TEST, LOCALHOST, INVALID and EXAMPLE). Following the publication of , the top-level domain names "LOCAL" and "ONION" were added.

While some of the entries in the Registry document the use of a DNS-like namespace by non-DNS name resolution protocols (LOCALHOST, LOCAL, ONION), other entries are included for different reasons (e.g. EXAMPLE.ORG, EXAMPLE.COM and EXAMPLE.NET are reserved for use in documentation; so-called reverse zones corresponding to addresses are special in the sense that they are usually non-unique).
This document specifically explores the problems in the use of to justify the reservation of top-level domains in the DNS. Use of with reference to other domain names is not discussed.

section.title: Clear and Specific Guidelines
section.t: Experience with the review and ultimate approval of and has revealed a need for objective criteria and a clear process that encourages and facilitates useful registrations of top-level domains in the Registry without fear of abuse, and with consistent and adequate consideration of all future requests.

section.title: Evaluation Process
section.t: specifies the way in which "an IETF 'Standards Action' or 'IESG Approval' document" should present answers to the questions described in , but does not describe the process by which the answers should be evaluated.

For example, it is not clear whether the evaluation of a document which requests additions to the Registry should be performed by the IESG, by the IAB, by the DNSOP working group, by an ad-hoc working group, by expert review or any combination of those approaches.

At the time of writing, the DNSOP working group charter does not clearly indicate that DNSOP is the proper venue for the evaluation to be carried out, although it also does not prohibit this work taking place there.

As an illustration of the inconsistency that has been observed already, was published as an AD-sponsored individual submission in the INT area, and the IESG evaluation record does not reveal any discussion of the reservation of the LOCAL top-level domain in the DNS; , however, was published as a working group document through DNSOP, and an extensive discussion by the IESG on the merits of the request took place.

section.title: Coordination between the IETF and ICANN
section.t: The policy surrounding the implementation and management of top-level domains in the DNS has been developed using a multi-stakeholder process convened by ICANN. At the time of writing, the process by which most new top-level domains are reviewed includes the ability for applications to be rejected on technical grounds; for example, an application for "LOCALHOST" would not be approved.

Whilst discussing the particular attributes that make a domain name special, notes that "the act of defining such a special name creates a higher-level protocol rule, above ICANN's management of allocatable names on the public Internet." This declaration may well be uncontentious, perhaps accommodated by the technical review alluded to above. However, a clear understanding of the operational coordination required to avoid conflicts seems prudent, in the interests of maintaining the stability of the naming system as a whole and protecting end-users from confusion or harm.

section.title: Clear Expectations
section.t: Each of the seven questions posed by has the potential to expose special handling of particular queries in the DNS by particular audiences. However, it is not clear what any of those audiences might reasonably expect as a result of a succesful request to add a top-level domain to the Registry.

For example, reservation of a top-level domain by the IETF does not guarantee that queries for names within a reserved domain will not be sent over the Internet. The requirements of the operators of recursive resolvers in the DNS cannot be relied upon to be implemented; the impact on the operators of DNS authoritative servers hence cannot be reliably assumed to be zero. In the case of , leakage of ONION queries on the Internet might lead to disclosure of private information that, in some cases, might pose a risk to the personal safety of end-users.

The Registry as published at the time of writing does not include direct guidance for any of the seven audiences, relying instead upon a reference to a published RFC that might well be opaque to many readers ( is a seventy-page protocol specification, for example, which is arguably not the most expressive way to set expectations of non-technical end-users).

Useful reservations of top-level domains should be accompanied by the existence of realistic expectations of each of the seven audiences, and the evaluation of particular requests should consider the practical liklihood of those expectations being met and the implications if they are not.

section.title: Protocol Identifiers in Names
section.t: The lack of a more elegant way to specify a name resolution protocol in (for example) a URI amounts to an architectural problem. However, it is not clear that this is still a problem that can be solved; it could be observed that in the absence of a more elegant alternative, a pragmatic choice to embed priotocol selectors as namespace tokens has effectively already been made. Although the reservation of names in the DNS namespace can be made at any level, the three examples above demonstrate use-cases for reservation at the top-level, and hence that case must be considered.

In the IAB noted that
To remain a global network, the Internet requires the existence of a globally unique public name space. The DNS name space is a hierarchical name space derived from a single, globally unique root."
Maintaining a globally-unique public namespace that supports different name resolution protocols is hence an architectural requirement, and some facility for reservation of top-level domains in the DNS is necessary.

section.title: Separation of Protocol and Policy
section.t: does not address the choice of domain name to be added to the Registry when considering a particular case of special-use.

In the case of LOCALHOST, LOCAL and ONION, use of particular domain names was already in use by a substantial population of end-users, and the practical cost of a transition perhaps justifies their continued use. However, when formulating a general process for future such reservations, prior use of particular names cannot be assumed.

In the case where the technical requirement is for reservation of a unique domain name, and not any domain name in particular, the IETF should consider whether the choice of name is really a technical matter, or a policy decision that is best addressed in other venues.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: This document aims to provide a problem statement that will inform future work. Whilst security and privacy are fundamental considerations, this document expects that that future work will include such analysis, and hence no attempt is made to do so here.

section.title: Pithy Quotes from History
section.t:
The question has arisen as to how the toplevel naming authority decides who gets a toplevel name and who must get by with a non-toplevel name. The suggestion was made by MOCKAPETRIS@USC-ISIF that perhaps the existing toplevel nameholders might vote on whether the applicant for a new toplevel name should be granted, with a majority needed for approval. It seems to me this might produce a clique whereby whoever initially gains power will hold it and prevent its "enemies" from getting in too. This will make the toplevel rather less than universal.
(E-mail from Robert Elton Maas to the namedroppers mailing list on 9 November 1983)

My basic point is that as a world-wide network evolves it is ridiculous to force people to name resources in terms of one static hierarchy which very closely resembles the current internetwork topology (as the current scheme does). What we are eventually going to require is a distributed expert for making sense out of a name someone hands it. There will be no simple algorithm to be written on one page of an RFC that will suffice to resolve a name. Rather, a number of heuristics will let a resolver make sense out of a given name by querying other experts which it suspects may be more knowledgeable about the name than it is, or by forwarding a piece of mail to an expert which is at least one level closer to the destination in some hierarchy.
(E-mail from Peter Karp to the namedroppers mailing list on 8 February 1984)
